poem:
"Fade-Out of the Lustful Lens"

Rich films of Saltburn and Strangers,
sprinkle less salt, 
don fewer masks, 
screen timid, not strangers.
Aye, the red curtain falls,
on Hollywood's sultry scrawl.

Yet, through this lustless haze, 
seeks no wizened Gen Z gaze.
Is it loss or gain?
Less fleshy screen,
more human pain -
the celluloid reign,
forever changed.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Keeping it clean: Hollywood sex scenes decline by 40% The advent of explicit films such as Poor Things, Saltburn and All of Us Strangers has been heralded as marking a revival of sex on screen – in the face of a reported lack of interest from Gen Z audiences. However, a new report suggests that in fact the Hollywood sex scene is declining fast: there is almost 40% less sexual content in major films than". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
